div.p: As always so now, dear Dr Gray, your letters give me great delight, as they are so full of genial generosity.

How short sighted your Congress would act, after incurring the expense of a great naval expedition,
United States Exploring Expedition, 1838-1842, under Charles Wilkes. to withhold the means of bringing to publicity all its important results, among which yours are not the least, no among those of most lasting importance. It is a glorious task also for you to grasp California & the other western states for your works & volumes. So we shall at last enjoy the use of a complete flora of the United states, and perhaps you will finish off with what comes to you phytographically as a just share Mexico. Dr Lawson meanwhile seems to deal effectually with Canada,
George Lawson; see publication list in Proceedings and transactions of the Royal Society of Canada, series 1, vol. 12, pp. 49-52 (1895), but in his entry in the Dictionary of Canadian Biography, Suzanne Zeller warns 'it must be used with caution since it contains some inaccuracies' (http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/lawson_george_12E.html accessed 11 December 2020). Lawson did not complete a full Flora of Canada but published a series of papers on specific groups. as Grisebach has done largely with the Antilles.
Grisebach (1864).

As you suggest I will write to Dr. Hillebrand in Heidelberg concerning Hawaian plants. I knew him early in life, but have lost sight of him for years.
M met Hillebrand in Adelaide in 1849. I possess in my private library your volume on Commodore Wilkes plants with the folio Atlas,
A. Gray (1854), A. Gray (1856). and have largely quoted both in allusion to the New Hebrides plants.
B73.13.01.

If vol. VII of the Fragmenta
B72.02.08. is not yet gone to you, it will be sent; vol. VIII will appear in a few months.
B75.04.06.

Pray convey to Agassiz's son my condolence at the loss of his illustrious father, from whom I enjoyed much encouragement.
Alexander Agassiz; Louis Agassiz died on 14 December 1873. Young Agassiz will perhaps let me know, what he most requires from here. To contribute material from every branch of zoology is in this expensive country too costly for me; but if any special set of objects are just wanted for really forthcoming works, I would willingly send what I can to any London Adress of his Museum so far free.

div.p:
I have lost entirely sight of the excellent and ingenious Mr. Osborn.
J. W. Osborne.
